bibl.title: Letter from George M. Sternberg to Walter Reed, January 19, 1894

div1.p: Sternberg discusses his theory of yellow fever and the necessary preventative measures to combat the spread of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from George M. Sternberg to Walter Reed, January 19, 1894
div1.opener:
Subject
202
FC
War Department
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, January 19, 1894.
My Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
Your letter of the 15th is at hand. What you say is en-
tirely correct. Yellow Fever is non-contagious in the same sense
that Cholera and Typhoid Fever are non-contagious. That is, under
ordinary conditions the patient does not directly communicate the
disease to others associated with him. But, like Typhoid Fever
and Cholera, there is something given off from the bodies of Yellow
Fever patients which, under favorable local and meteorological con-
ditions, may multiply outside of the body and give rise to an ex-
tended epidemic. And it seems to me extremely probable that, as
in Typhoid Fever and in Cholera, this “something” is a living germ
which is present in the discharges from the bowels of infected in-
dividuals; and that when such infectious discharges are thrown out
upon the ground or in shallow privy vaults, etc., especially in the
presence of organic material of animal origin and in a tropical cli-
mate, the living germ is capable of rapid multiplication. This being
the case the same precautions must be taken with reference to the ex-
clusion of Yellow Fever patients, and their isolation if they are
landed upon our shores, as are necessary in the case of the strictly
contagious diseases, such as Small-Pox. If our exposed seaports
were in such a sanitary condition that the hypothetical germ con-
203
tained in the alvine discharges of the sick could not find a
nidus for its multiplication outside of the body of an infected
individual there would be no danger of an extension of the dis-
ease. Or, if we could be absolutely sure that the discharges
were thoroughly disinfected from the moment that the germ of
the disease was present in them, we might dispense with isola-
tion of the patient. But it is evident that the only reliable
means of disinfecting the excreta is to have complete control of
the sick or of those recently arrived from infected localities,
who may possibly carry the germ in the contents of the bowels in
advance of an attack, or even in the case of individuals when no
attack is likely to be developed.

Taking this view of the case, the preventive measures to
be used against Yellow Fever are similar to those to be used against
Cholera, and include exclusion by quarantine regulations, isolation
of cases landed upon our shores, disinfection of excreta, and cloth-
ing which may possibly be soiled by the alvine discharges of the
sick, together with municipal sanitation, and in time of epidemic
the removal of all unprotected persons from infected areas.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Geo. M. Sternberg Dr. Joseph Y. Porter,
Key West, Florida.
